facts.text: District Magistrate of Hooghly passed an order on May 9, 1973 under sub-section (1) read with sub-section (2) of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 for the detention of the petitioner to prevent him from acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate of Hooghly passed an order on May 9, 1973 under sub-section  1  read with sub- section  2  of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act No, 26 of 1971  for the detention of the petitioner with a view to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to--the companymunity.

facts.text: Petitioner was arrested on May 14, 1973 and was served with the order of detention as also the grounds of detention together with vernacular translation thereof.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the, detention order, the petitioner was arrested on May 14, 1973 and was served with the order of detention as also the grounds of detention together with vernacular translation thereof.

facts.text: Report about the making of the detention order was sent by the District Magistrate to the State Government and the said Government approved the detention order on May 18, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Report about the making of the detention order was sent by the District Magistrate to the, State Government and the said Government approved the detention order on May 18, 1973.

facts.text: The case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board by the State Government on June 5, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board by the State Government on June 5, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner sent a representation against his detention and the same was received by the State Government on June 2, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner sent a representation against his detention and the same was received by the State Government on June 2, 1973.

facts.text: State Government rejected the representation on June 4, 1973 and forwarded the same to the Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government rejected the representation on June, 4. 1973 and forwarded the same to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Advisory Board after considering the representation and hearing the petitioner in person made report to the State Government on July 11, 1973 expressing opinion that there was sufficient cause for the detention.

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board. after companysidering the representation and hearing the petitioner in person made report to the, State Government on July 11, 1973. Opinion was expressed by the Board that there, was sufficient cause for the, detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed the order for the detention of the petitioner on July 30, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On July 30. 1973 the State Government companyfirmed the order for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner filed petition under section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure before the Calcutta High Court which was dismissed as per judgment dated July 4, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in the meantime filed petition under section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure before the Calcutta High Court. The said Petition was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court and was dismissed as per judgment dated July 4, 1973.

facts.text: Present petition under article 32 was sent by the petitioner from jail on July 23, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The present Petition under article 32 of the Constitution was thereafter sent by the petitioner from jail on July 23, 1973 for the issue of a writ of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner claims representation was sent by him from jail on May 25, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged that the representation wag sent by him from jail on May 25, 1973 and that a period of 10 days elapsed from the date of the submission of the representation and its actual disposal.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges detention order contained blanks which were filled subsequent to signing by District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: It has next been argued on behalf of the petitioner that the detention order companytained blanks which were filled in subsequent to the signing of that order by the District Magistrate.

facts.text: State Government received representation on June 2, 1973 after forwarded by Superintendent, Hooghly Jail and rejected it on June 4, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: it would appear from the affidavit filed by Shri Sukumar Sen that the representation sent by the petitioner was received by the State Government in its Home Department on June 2, 1973 after it had been forwarded by the Superintendent, Hooghly Jail. The said representation was then companysidered and was rejected by the State Government on June 4. 1973.

facts.text: On 31-3-73 in early hours, petitioner and associates smuggled rice by Tarakeshwar-Sheoraphuli local train from non-rationed to rationed areas of Hooghly and Howrah, seized 14 quintals 55 kgs at Kamarkundu by anti-smuggling staff, attacked them, attempted escape, fire opened in self-defence, two associates arrested, disruption in train services.

anchor.surface_text: On 31-3-73 in the early hours of the morning you and your associates were found to smuggle rice by train No. of 2 Dn.  Tarakeshwar--Sheofaphuli local  from number- rationed areas to rationing areas of Hooghly and Howrah District in companytravention of the provisions of the West Bengal Rice and Paddy  Restriction on Movement  Order, 1968. At 04.27 hrs. of date when the train reached Kamarkundu Railway Station the anti-smuggling staff of Dankuni P.S.checkpost under the companymand of S.I. Biren Das, seized 14 quintals and 55 kgs. of smuggled rice belonging to you and your associates after rummaging the said train. At this you and your associates launched a violent attack on the anti- smuggling party and threw ballasts towards them causing injuries an the persons of some of the anti-smuggling staff with a view to scare them away and thus attempted to escape with the smuggled rice. The anti-smuggling party had to open fire in self-defence and companyld be able to arrest two of your associates on chase when you and your other associates managed to escape. As a result of this. there was serious disruption in the smooth running of train services on Tarakeshwar-Howrah line causing inconvenience to the travelling public and transshipment of companymodities essential- to the companymunity.

facts.text: On 12-4-73 at 11-21 hrs, petitioner and associates boarded Bombay-Howrah Mail with rice to smuggle to Howrah industrial belts, alarm chain pulled, stopped at Chandanpore, petitioner fled leaving 5 quintals, total 41 quintals 75 kgs seized from associates who escaped, value Rs.10,000.

anchor.surface_text: On 12-4-73 at 11-21 hrs. you and your associates were found to board train No. 4 Dn.  Bombay-Howrah Mail  with huge quantity of rice with a view to smuggle them from numberrational areas to the industrial belts of Howrah in companytravention of the provisions of the West Bengal Rice and Paddy  Restriction on Movement  Order, 1908 when the train stopped at Jaugram Railway Station on Burdwan-Howrah Chord line due to alarm chain pulling by some of your associates as per previous arrange- ments, S. P. N. O. Dey of G.R.P. Enforcement Branch, Howrah with his staff who were travelling by the said train companyld be able to stop the train at Chandanpore Railway Station with the help of the Guard of the train. On seeing the S.I. and his Party, you jumped down from the train and fled away from there leaving behind the bags of smuggled rice weighing 5 quintals. The S.I. and his staff companyld also be able to seize 41 quintals and 75 kgs. of smuggled rice from the possession of your other associates who also managed to escape with you. The total value of the smug- gled rice seized was about Rs. 10,000/-

facts.text: On 23-4-73 at 12-20 hrs, petitioner seen in 3rd class compartment of Burdwan-Howrah local at Kamarkundu with two gunny bags containing 169 kgs rice without permit, arrested by anti-smuggling staff under S.I. J.C. Das.

anchor.surface_text: On 23-4-73 at 12-20 hrs. when train No. C-258 Down  Burdwan-Howrah Chord line local  arrived at Kamarkundu Railway Station, the anti-smuggling party of Howrah G.R.P. Cordoning saw You in a 3rd class companypartment of the said train with the bags of smuggled rice in companytravention of the provisions of the West Bengal Rice and Paddy  Restriction on Movement  Order, 1968. The anti-smuggling staff under the companymand of S.I., J. C. Das arrested You from the 3rd class companypartment of the said train with two gunny bags companytaining 169 kgs. of rice which you were carrying without any permit or authority,

facts.text: Petition under Art 32 is Writ Petition No. 1641 of 1973 in original jurisdiction for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 1641 of 1973. Under Art 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of a Writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Affidavit of Shri Sukumar Sen, Deputy Secretary, Home (Special) Department filed in opposition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition has been resisted by the State of West Bengal and the affidavit of Shri Sukumar Sen, Deputy Secretary, Home  Special  Department has been filed in opposition to the petition.

facts.text: Petitioner argued delay in considering representation vitiates detention.

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued in the first instance by Mr. Majumdar that there was delay on the part of the State Government in companysidering the representation of the petitioner and such delay vitiates the detention.

facts.text: Petitioner argued grounds of detention vague.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Majumdar that the grounds of detention on the basis of which the order for the detention was made were vague.

facts.text: Court finds no delay in disposal of representation by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention. in our opinion, is without any force. it would appear from the affidavit filed by Shri Sukumar Sen that the representation sent by the petitioner was received by the State Government in its Home Department on June 2, 1973 after it had been forwarded by the Superintendent, Hooghly Jail. The said representation was then companysidered and was rejected by the State Government on June 4. 1973. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any delay in the disposal of the representation of the petitioner by the State Government.

facts.text: Court rejects allegation of blanks in detention order as petitioner not present when signed and no cogent ground.

anchor.surface_text: This allegation has been denied in the affidavit filed on behalf of the State Government and, in our opinion, there is numbercogent ground to accept the companyrectness of the allegation. The petitioner was admittedly number present at the time the detention order was signed by the District Magistrate and. as such, he cannot be in a position to state whether the detention order companytained blanks when it was signed by the District Magistrate. The mere fact that the detention order is on a cyclostyled sheet wherein necessary particulars were filled in ink would number go to show that the particulars in ink were filled in sub- sequent to the signing of the detention order.

facts.text: Court finds grounds of detention specify date, time, place, nature of activities, sufficient to apprise petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the, above that the date, time and place of each of the incidents were specified in the grounds. Particulars were also given regarding the nature of the activities of the petitioner. The facts stated in the grounds of detention were sufficient to apprise the petitioner of the precise activities on account of which the detention order bad been made.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.

arguments.claim: Courts look with disfavour upon vague grounds of detention because they fail to convey the precise objectionable activity and prevent effective representation.

anchor.surface_text: The, courts look with disfavour upon vague grounds of detention, because such grounds fail to companyvey to the detenu the precise activity on account of which he is being detained. The detenu is thus prevented from making an effective representation which he night possible have, if he had been apprised of the objection able activity which led to his detention.

arguments.claim: The grounds of detention in this case are not vague as requisite details were conveyed and no prejudice caused to petitioner in making representation.

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, as in the present case the requisite details of the activity for which the order for detention was made have been companyveyed to the detenu and he is number shown to have been prejudiced or handicapped in making in effective representation, the argument about the vagueness of grounds of detention must plainly be held to be number tenable.

arguments.claim: There is no delay in disposal of the representation by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: This contention. in our opinion, is without any force. it would appear from the affidavit filed by Shri Sukumar Sen that the representation sent by the petitioner was received by the State Government in its Home Department on June 2, 1973 after it had been forwarded by the Superintendent, Hooghly Jail. The said representation was then companysidered and was rejected by the State Government on June 4. 1973.

anchor.surface_text: This contention. in our opinion, is without any force. it would appear from the affidavit filed by Shri Sukumar Sen that the representation sent by the petitioner was received by the State Government in its Home Department on June 2, 1973 after it had been forwarded by the Superintendent, Hooghly Jail. The said representation was then considered and was rejected by the State Government on June 4. 1973. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any delay in the disposal of the representation of the petitioner by the State Government.

holdings.text: there is no cogent ground to accept the correctness of the allegation [of blanks in detention order]

anchor.surface_text: This allegation has been denied in the affidavit filed on behalf of the State Government and, in our opinion, there is no cogent ground to accept the correctness of the allegation. The petitioner was admittedly not present at the time the detention order was signed by the District Magistrate and. as such, he cannot be in a position to state whether the detention order contained blanks when it was signed by the District Magistrate. The mere fact that the detention order is on a cyclostyled sheet wherein necessary particulars were filled in ink would not go to show that the particulars in ink were filled in sub- sequent to the signing of the detention order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegation denied by affidavit; petitioner absent at signing, unable to know; cyclostyled form with ink normal practice

holdings.text: The facts stated in the grounds of detention were sufficient to apprise the petitioner of the precise activities on account of which the detention order had been made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grounds specify date, time, place, nature of smuggling incidents; sufficient particulars provided

holdings.text: It cannot in the circumstances be said that the Petitioner was in any way handicapped in making an effective representation

anchor.surface_text: It cannot in the circumstances be said that the Petitioner was in any way handicapped in making an effective representation- The fact that the names of the associates of the Petitioner were number mentioned in the grounds of detention would number go to show that they suffered from the infirmity of vagueness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner not prejudiced despite lack of associates' names; able to make effective representation

anchor.surface_text: State of West Bengal and the affidavit of Shri Sukumar Sen, Deputy Secretary, Home  Special  Department has been filed in opposition to the petition.

edges.explanation: Holding of no delay addresses the issue of whether there was delay

anchor.surface_text: This contention. in our opinion, is without any force. it would appear from the affidavit filed by Shri Sukumar Sen that the representation sent by the petitioner was received by the State Government in its Home Department on June 2, 1973 after it had been forwarded by the Superintendent, Hooghly Jail. The said representation was then considered and was rejected by the State Government on June 4. 1973. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any delay in the disposal of the representation of the petitioner by the State Government.
The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding on period length addresses delay issue

anchor.surface_text: It has been urged that the representation wag sent by him from jail on May 25, 1973 and that a period of 10 days elapsed from the date of the submission of the representation and its actual disposal. The above period cannot also be said to be so inordinately long as might affect the validity of the detention.
The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.
as then companysidered and was rejected by the State Government on June 4. 1973. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any delay in the di

edges.explanation: Holding rejects allegation of blanks in detention order, directly addressing the issue

anchor.surface_text: This allegation has been denied in the affidavit filed on behalf of the State Government and, in our opinion, there is no cogent ground to accept the correctness of the allegation. The petitioner was admittedly not present at the time the detention order was signed by the District Magistrate and. as such, he cannot be in a position to state whether the detention order contained blanks when it was signed by the District Magistrate. The mere fact that the detention order is on a cyclostyled sheet wherein necessary particulars were filled in ink would not go to show that the particulars in ink were filled in sub- sequent to the signing of the detention order.
The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Sufficiency of facts in grounds to apprise of precise activities supports that detenu not handicapped in effective representation due to specific details.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the, above that the date, time and place of each of the incidents were specified in the grounds. Particulars were also given regarding the nature of the activities of the petitioner. The facts stated in the grounds of detention were sufficient to apprise the petitioner of the precise activities on account of which the detention order bad been made.
The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.

The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, as in the present case the requisite details of the activity for which the order for detention was made have been conveyed to the detenu and he is number shown to have been prejudiced or handicapped in making in effective representation, the argument about the vagueness of grounds of detention must plainly be held to be number tenable.
The petition companysequently fails and is dismissed.
